questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-month history of penile pain. The pain has become worse over the past 2 weeks, especially on erection. He says that his penis curves downward and does not stay erect during sexual intercourse. He feels embarrassed about his penis and has avoided dates and sexual relationships. Previously, he was sexually active with multiple female partners. Physical examination shows a palpable plaque in the distal third of the penis. A disorder of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The dartos fascia is a thin layer of connective tissue located just below the skin that surrounds the penis and scrotum. Peyronie disease does not affect this structure.

B) CORRECT:

Peyronie disease is a fibroproliferative disorder that affects the tunica albuginea of the penis. The etiology of Peyronie disease is not well understood but has been associated with penile trauma, including both acute traumatic events and repetitive microtrauma during sexual activity. The consequent wound healing is thought to result in abnormal fibrous plaque formation. Affected patients may experience pain, irregular engorgement, and erectile dysfunction due to an abnormal curvature of the penis. Treatment includes oral pentoxifylline or intralesional collagenase injections; surgical repair may be necessary in refractory cases.
Image Description:

Photograph of an erect penis showing an abnormal downward curvature.

C) INCORRECT:

The preputium penis (the foreskin) is retractable tissue that covers the glans penis. Conditions that affect the foreskin include balanoposthitis and phimosis, not Peyronie disease.

D) INCORRECT:

The corpus spongiosum is a sponge-like tissue ventral to the corpus cavernosa. The corpus spongiosum contains the urethra and prevents its collapse during erection. Conditions that affect the corpus spongiosum include priapism, not Peyronie disease.

E) INCORRECT:

The glans penis is the distal end of the corpus spongiosum. It is attached to the frenulum, covered by the foreskin, and contains the external urethral meatus. Conditions that affect the glans penis include balanitis and balanoposthitis, not Peyronie disease.

F) INCORRECT:

The corpus cavernosum is a paired structure dorsal to the corpus spongiosum and contains the erectile tissue of the penis. Corpus cavernosa (as well as the tunica albuginea) are affected in penile fractures. Peyronie disease does not affect this structure.
questions.hint: The combination of penile pain and a palpable plaque with progressive erectile dysfunction due to penile curvature is consistent with Peyronie disease.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of redness and swelling of the head of his penis for the past 2 days. The mother says that he has constantly been scratching his genital area since yesterday. She has also noticed an unpleasant smell when changing his diaper. One week ago, the boy had a diaper rash that slightly improved with an over-the-counter ointment. He is uncircumcised and has no history of serious illness. The boy's parents, as well as his two older sisters, are well. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the genital area shows erythematous plaques and scattered pustules in the perianal area, inguinal creases, and on the glans penis and foreskin as well as edema of the glans penis. A white, curd-like discharge appears from under the foreskin. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. In addition to counseling on proper genital hygiene, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

White curd-like discharge from under the foreskin, the presence of scattered satellite pustules, the involvement of skin folds (inguinal creases), and persistent diaper dermatitis (> 3 days) strongly suggest fungal balanoposthitis as a result of candidal superinfection of diaper dermatitis. In infants, fungal balanoposthitis in association with candida diaper dermatitis is usually a clinical diagnosis and empiric topical antifungal agents (e.g., clotrimazole) are indicated to treat this local mucocutaneous dermatophyte infection. In addition, barrier ointments should be applied 2–3 times daily until resolution is achieved. Further measures to control the local inflammation include sitz baths and avoidance of irritants (e.g., soap, talc powder), as well as counseling on genital hygiene.

In prepubertal patients that have balanoposthitis with urethral discharge, diagnostic workup for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is indicated and, if STIs are confirmed, evaluation for sexual abuse should follow.
Image Description:

There is diffuse dark erythema with confluent papules, scaling, and satellite lesions of the perianal and infraumbilical region. Skin folds are involved.

These findings suggest Candida diaper dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is indicated in the case of bacterial balanoposthitis due to group A Streptococci (GAS). Patients with GAS balanoposthitis typically have a history of recent or ongoing GAS infection (e.g., tonsillopharyngitis, perianal streptococcal dermatitis) or contact with an infected individual (e.g., family member). Perianal streptococcal dermatitis typically manifests with bright red erythema most prominent in the perianal area, rather than with widespread pustules and plaques extending to the inguinal creases. Satellite pustules and a curd-like discharge from under the foreskin suggest a different etiology of balanoposthitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is indicated in genital herpes simplex virus infection, which can cause balanoposthitis. Genital herpes is classically associated with painful and pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region, rather than plaques and satellite pustules. Moreover, a white curd-like discharge would not be expected. Genital herpes is uncommon in toddlers and would warrant evaluation for sexual abuse.

D) INCORRECT:

Circumcision (or alternatively preputioplasty) is a treatment option for patients with balanoposthitis that is recurrent or fails conservative treatment because the foreskin predisposes to future infections. This patient has neither of these indications, so another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone can be used in the treatment of irritant balanoposthitis. The presence of satellite pustules and white curd-like discharge from under the foreskin strongly suggest a different, infectious cause of balanoposthitis, for which topical corticosteroids are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Erythema and edema of both the glans penis and the foreskin indicate balanoposthitis. This patient's history of a pruritic malodorous diaper rash (diaper dermatitis) for one week and the white curd-like discharge suggest a specific etiology.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because she cannot retract the foreskin of his penis while bathing him. He was born at term and has been healthy since. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He has no family history of serious illness. He is physically active and can use 2-word sentences. His mother says that he likes doll play with his 6-year-old sister. His diet consists of solid foods and cow milk. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well. He is at the 70th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. On genital examination, his penis is of age-appropriate size and the foreskin is not retractable; both testes are palpable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform forcible retraction of the foreskin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment, such as circumcision or vertical incision, is recommended in patients with phimosis who have not responded to conservative treatment. In boys aged < 5 years with physiologic phimosis, different management should be considered initially.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical bacitracin can be used in the treatment of balanitis or balanoposthitis, which can result in the development of secondary phimosis. This patient, however, has no signs of balanitis or balanoposthitis, such as pain, itching and irritation, or dysuria. His phimosis is most likely physiologic and requires different management.

C) INCORRECT:

Dorsal slit reduction can be used in patients with paraphimosis, which is characterized by an inability to return the retracted foreskin to its original position over the glans. This patient presents with nonretractable foreskin, which, in a young boy, suggests physiologic phimosis and requires different management.

D) INCORRECT:

Forcible foreskin retraction is contraindicated in patients with physiologic phimosis because it is painful, traumatic, and can lead to fibrosis, which is a risk factor for the development of pathologic phimosis.

E) CORRECT:

Full phimosis in the absence of preputial scarring, infection, or inflammation, is considered physiologic in boys aged < 5 years and usually resolves spontaneously. Conservative measures such as gentle stretching exercises (to avoid trauma and consequent fibrosis) and topical corticosteroids can be considered to accelerate foreskin retractability. Patients and their parents should also be counseled on the importance of preputial hygiene for the prevention of infection. Surgery (i.e., circumcision or vertical incision) should be considered in patients who do not respond to conservative therapy.

Pathologic phimosis can result from trauma (e.g., forcible retraction of the foreskin in patients with physiologic phimosis) or infection (i.e., balanitis, balanoposthitis). In patients with pathologic phimosis, topical corticosteroids and gentle stretching exercises are also considered first-line treatment, and surgery should be considered for those who do not respond to conservative management.
questions.hint: A nonretractable foreskin in an otherwise healthy 2-year-old boy indicates full, physiologic phimosis.

questions.text:
An otherwise healthy 6-year-old boy is evaluated in the emergency department for penile pain. His mother reports that he was in his usual state of health this morning without complaints. However, after bathing himself 2 hours ago, he has been complaining of penile pain and seems to appear uncomfortable with movement. He has no dysuria, abdominal pain, back pain, nausea, or vomiting.
On examination, the boy is afebrile. His heart rate is 115 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and his blood pressure is 96/62 mm Hg. His penis is visibly swollen (figure).
The scrotum is nontender, and the cremasteric reflexes are intact bilaterally. No urethral foreign bodies are evident, and no hair or fiber tourniquets are present around the penis. The rest of the boy’s examination is unremarkable.
After appropriate analgesia is achieved, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal penile shaft
Inject 0.5 cc of 1% lidocaine with epinephrine into each side of the penis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paraphimosis is a painful urologic emergency in which the foreskin of an uncircumcised or partially circumcised penis is retracted fully behind the glans. This leads to swelling and irritation with subsequent inability to pull the foreskin back over the glans. Prolonged retraction can result in tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Paraphimosis occurs when a child, a child’s caregiver, or a health care professional retracts the foreskin and leaves it in the retracted position in the setting of genital cleansing, self-manipulation, penile examination, or urethral catheterization.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management approach for paraphimosis in a child is manual reduction of the foreskin after adequate analgesia is achieved.

B) INCORRECT:

Use of intracavernous papaverine results in penile vasodilation, which could increase edema and may cause priapism.

C) INCORRECT:

Applying a tourniquet to the proximal penile shaft would not reduce distal swelling, so it should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

After appropriate analgesia, if gentle manual pressure applied for 10 to 15 minutes is unsuccessful — or if a patient has necrosis or ulcerations of the foreskin or glans, or any other genital lesions — urgent surgical consultation is required.

E) INCORRECT:

Although paraphimosis is an emergency and reduction should be performed urgently, a patient should be given adequate analgesia before the reduction. The analgesia is often achieved with a topical anesthetic without epinephrine; a penile block or conscious sedation may be required. When needed, a penile block should be done with an injectable anesthetic without epinephrine, as use of epinephrine may lead to tissue ischemia.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because she cannot retract the foreskin of his penis while bathing him. He was born at term and has been healthy since. He is at the 70th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. On genital examination, his penis is of age-appropriate size and the foreskin is not retractable; both testes are palpable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father due to difficulty retracting the foreskin of his penis since toddlerhood. He reports bulging of the foreskin during urination, which resolves afterward without pain or bleeding. He is otherwise healthy and up to date on vaccinations. On examination, the tip of the foreskin appears tight, and gentle traction reveals only partial retraction with no inflammation or discharge.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phimosis manifests as the inability to fully retract the foreskin over the glans penis. In children, this condition is often physiological and resolves with age. The boy's long-standing difficulty retracting the foreskin without pain or infection suggests a tight preputial ring. Examination reveals a tight foreskin tip allowing only partial retraction, consistent with phimosis. The absence of pain, erythema, or discharge indicates a benign condition without secondary infection or scarring. Phimosis results from the natural adhesion between the foreskin and glans, which typically separates over time.

Key learning point: Phimosis is characterized by the inability to retract the foreskin over the glans penis, often presenting with foreskin ballooning during urination in young boys.

B) INCORRECT:

Balanitis involves inflammation of the glans, presenting with erythema, edema, and pain. The boy's history of a tight foreskin without pain, erythema, or discharge suggests a mechanical issue rather than an inflammatory process, making balanitis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Paraphimosis occurs when the retracted foreskin cannot return to its normal position, leading to pain and swelling. It is an acute condition requiring urgent intervention. The boy's lack of acute pain, swelling, or vascular compromise, along with the foreskin's inability to fully retract, differentiates it from paraphimosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypospadias is characterized by an abnormally positioned urethral meatus on the ventral penis, often causing an atypical urinary stream. The boy's symptoms of a tight foreskin and bulging during urination do not align with hypospadias, as there is no mention of an abnormal meatal location or urinary stream.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because she has been unable to retract his foreskin during bathing. He was born at term and has been healthy. His height is at the 70th percentile and his weight is at the 60th percentile. On genital examination, his penis is of age-appropriate size, the foreskin is not retractable, and both testes are palpable. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform forcible retraction of the foreskin.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Forcible foreskin retraction is contraindicated in patients with physiologic phimosis because it is painful, traumatic, and can lead to fibrosis, which is a risk factor for the development of pathologic phimosis.

B) CORRECT:

Full phimosis in the absence of preputial scarring, infection, or inflammation, is considered physiologic in boys aged < 5 years and usually resolves spontaneously. Conservative measures such as gentle stretching exercises (to avoid trauma and consequent fibrosis) and topical corticosteroids can be considered to accelerate foreskin retractability. Patients and their parents should also be counseled on the importance of preputial hygiene for the prevention of infection. Surgery (i.e., circumcision or vertical incision) should be considered in patients who do not respond to conservative therapy.

Pathologic phimosis can result from trauma (e.g., forcible retraction of the foreskin in patients with physiologic phimosis) or infection (i.e., balanitis, balanoposthitis). In patients with pathologic phimosis, topical corticosteroids and gentle stretching exercises are also considered first-line treatment, and surgery should be considered for those who do not respond to conservative management.

Key learning point: Physiologic phimosis in young boys is normal and typically resolves spontaneously, so reassurance and proper hygiene are the most appropriate initial management.

C) INCORRECT:

Dorsal slit reduction can be used in patients with paraphimosis, which is characterized by an inability to return the retracted foreskin to its original position over the glans. This patient presents with nonretractable foreskin, which, in a young boy, suggests physiologic phimosis and requires different management.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment, such as circumcision or vertical incision, is recommended in patients with phimosis who have not responded to conservative treatment. In boys aged < 5 years with physiologic phimosis, different management should be considered initially.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical bacitracin can be used in the treatment of balanitis or balanoposthitis, which can result in the development of secondary phimosis. This patient, however, has no signs of balanitis or balanoposthitis, such as pain, itching and irritation, or dysuria. His phimosis is most likely physiologic and requires different management.
questions.hint: A nonretractable foreskin in an otherwise healthy 2-year-old boy indicates full, physiologic phimosis.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 6-year-old boy in the emergency department for penile pain. He has no dysuria, abdominal pain, back pain, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, he is afebrile. His heart rate is 115 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and blood pressure is 96/62 mm Hg. His penis is visibly swollen (see figure). The scrotum is nontender, and cremasteric reflexes are intact bilaterally. There are no urethral foreign bodies or hair/fiber tourniquets around the penis. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. After providing appropriate analgesia, which one of the following is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Inject 0.5 cc of 1% lidocaine with epinephrine into each side of the penis.
Apply a tourniquet to the proximal penile shaft.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paraphimosis is a painful urologic emergency in which the foreskin of an uncircumcised or partially circumcised penis is retracted fully behind the glans. This leads to swelling and irritation with subsequent inability to pull the foreskin back over the glans. Prolonged retraction can result in tissue ischemia and necrosis. Paraphimosis occurs when a child, a child’s caregiver, or a health care professional retracts the foreskin and leaves it in the retracted position in the setting of genital cleansing, self-manipulation, penile examination, or urethral catheterization.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management approach for paraphimosis in a child is manual reduction of the foreskin after adequate analgesia is achieved.

B) INCORRECT:

After appropriate analgesia, if gentle manual pressure applied for 10 to 15 minutes is unsuccessful — or if a patient has necrosis or ulcerations of the foreskin or glans, or any other genital lesions — urgent surgical consultation is required.

C) INCORRECT:

Although paraphimosis is an emergency and reduction should be performed urgently, a patient should be given adequate analgesia before the reduction. The analgesia is often achieved with a topical anesthetic without epinephrine; a penile block or conscious sedation may be required. When needed, a penile block should be done with an injectable anesthetic without epinephrine, as use of epinephrine may lead to tissue ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Use of intracavernous papaverine results in penile vasodilation, which could increase edema and may cause priapism.

E) INCORRECT:

Applying a tourniquet to the proximal penile shaft would not reduce distal swelling, so it should be avoided.

questions.text: A 52-year-old uncircumcised man presents with a 4-day history of penile discomfort and swelling. He reports two similar episodes in the past 8 months, both of which resolved with topical antifungal treatment. Examination is shown. He does not have urinary symptoms or fever. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe topical clotrimazole and recommend improved hygiene
Refer to urology for circumcision consultation
Perform subpreputial swab and KOH preparation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Recurrent candidal balanoposthitis that responds to antifungal treatment suggests an underlying metabolic cause and prompts screening for diabetes mellitus. Undiagnosed diabetes is a significant risk factor for recurrent candidal infections.

B) INCORRECT:

While topical antifungal treatment may be appropriate for candidal balanoposthitis, the recurrent nature of symptoms necessitates investigation for potential underlying medical conditions before initiating treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

While circumcision may be indicated for inflammatory or premalignant conditions, circumcision consultation is premature without first investigating the underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Although diagnostic testing can confirm candidal infection, this patient's clinical presentation and history of response to antifungal treatment already suggest candidal etiology. The priority is identifying underlying predisposing conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole may be appropriate for treatment, but the underlying cause must be investigated to prevent future episodes.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the ED reporting difficulty retracting his foreskin that began 3 months ago after he became sexually active. The patient reports mild discomfort during erection but no pain, discharge, or urinary symptoms. He had irritant balanoposthitis as a child but has no history of recurrent infections. Physical examination reveals an intact foreskin with a narrow preputial opening and a subtle white fibrous ring at the distal edge. There is no inflammation, edema, or scarring of the glans. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has pathologic phimosis, evidenced by the white fibrous ring at the preputial orifice and new-onset symptoms in a 19-year-old. Treatment involves topical corticosteroid therapy for 4–8 weeks before considering surgical intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and hygiene optimization are indicated for physiologic phimosis, but the presence of a white fibrous ring and onset of symptoms in a 19-year-old suggest pathologic phimosis. Reassurance and hygiene optimization alone are insufficient for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is premature. Conservative management with topical corticosteroids should be attempted first for pathologic phimosis, with surgical intervention reserved for treatment failure or complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is not indicated in this patient with no signs of infection such as inflammation, discharge, purulent material, or systemic symptoms. This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with pathologic phimosis rather than infectious etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction is the treatment for paraphimosis, not phimosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old uncircumcised man presents with penile pain and swelling that developed 3 hours after vigorous sex. Physical examination is shown. The patient reports intermittent urinary hesitancy. What is the most appropriate initial management approach?

choices.text: Topical anesthetic followed by manual reduction attempt
Prophylactic broad-spectrum antibiotics followed by manual reduction
Urgent urology consultation for dorsal slit procedure
Warm compress application and topical glucose before reduction
Suprapubic catheterization to address urinary obstruction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Paraphimosis requires immediate manual reduction to prevent penile necrosis. The most appropriate initial approach is adequate pain control with topical anesthesia or a dorsal penile block followed by manual reduction. Anesthetic products containing epinephrine should be avoided to prevent worsening vasoconstriction.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not indicated in the initial management of uncomplicated paraphimosis. Manual reduction with appropriate pain control is the standard first-line approach, and antibiotics are only considered if there are signs of secondary infection or tissue necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with uncomplicated paraphimosis, and surgical intervention is only performed if conservative measures are unsuccessful. The initial approach is manual reduction with appropriate pain control.

D) INCORRECT:

While topical glucose has an osmotic effect and may assist in reduction of paraphimosis, warm compresses are contraindicated, as heat can worsen edema and increase metabolic demands of already ischemic tissue. Ice packs are the appropriate adjunctive measure to reduce swelling.

E) INCORRECT:

While urinary obstruction may occur, addressing the paraphimosis itself is the priority to prevent penile ischemia and necrosis. Suprapubic catheterization does not resolve the underlying emergency condition.

questions.text: A 72-year-old uncircumcised man with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with a 2-week history of penile pain and difficulty urinating. He notes that the foreskin 'balloons' when he urinates. Physical examination reveals erythema and swelling of the glans and prepuce. Attempts to manipulate the foreskin are met with resistance. Which of the following is the most likely finding upon further physical examination?

choices.text: Ventral displacement of the urethral meatus
Palpable fibrous plaque on the dorsal penile shaft
Retracted prepuce entrapped behind the coronal sulcus
Inability to retract the prepuce over the glans
White, sclerotic patch involving the meatus and prepuce

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes hypospadias, a congenital anomaly where the urethral meatus is located on the underside of the penis. This condition is typically identified and surgically corrected in infancy or childhood and would not present as an acute issue in a 72-year-old man.

B) INCORRECT:

This finding is characteristic of Peyronie disease, which involves fibrosis of the tunica albuginea. Peyronie disease presents with penile pain during erections, palpable plaques, and penile curvature. This patient's symptoms relate to the foreskin and urination, not the penile shaft or erectile function.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes paraphimosis, a urologic emergency. In paraphimosis, the foreskin is retracted proximally but cannot be returned to its normal position, causing constriction and potential ischemia of the glans. This is the opposite of the patient's condition, as his foreskin cannot be retracted.

D) CORRECT:

Inability to retract the prepuce over the glans is a defining feature of phimosis. The patient's symptoms, including penile pain, difficulty urinating, and the classic sign of the foreskin ballooning during micturition, are all characteristic of a tight, non-retractile prepuce. This patient has acquired phimosis, likely secondary to recurrent or chronic balanoposthitis (inflammation of the glans and prepuce), a common complication in individuals with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The inflammation leads to scarring and stenosis of the preputial orifice. Management may include topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and scarring, or definitive surgical treatment with a dorsal slit procedure or circumcision, especially for recurrent or severe cases.

E) INCORRECT:

This describes balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO), also known as lichen sclerosus. While BXO is a common cause of acquired phimosis and meatal stenosis, it represents a potential underlying diagnosis rather than the primary physical finding. The immediate clinical problem described by the patient's symptoms is the non-retractile foreskin itself.
questions.hint: This patient’s clinical features are most likely consistent with acquired phimosis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because she cannot retract his foreskin during bathing. She reports no history of painful urination, a weak urinary stream, or swelling of the penis. The child is uncircumcised and is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, the penis is normal in size and appearance. The foreskin is non-retractile, and the urethral meatus is not visualized. There is no erythema, tenderness, scarring, or discharge observed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform manual dilation of the prepuce in the office
Reassure the mother and advise on routine hygiene
Refer the patient to pediatric urology for circumcision
Instruct the mother on gentle daily stretching exercises
Prescribe a course of topical betamethasone cream

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Forcible manual retraction or dilation of the prepuce is an outdated and potentially harmful practice. This maneuver is painful and risks causing significant trauma to the foreskin, including bleeding, fissures, and scarring. This can lead to the development of iatrogenic pathologic phimosis and should be avoided, especially in an asymptomatic child with a normal developmental variant.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has physiologic phimosis, a normal developmental condition in which the foreskin is not yet retractable due to congenital adhesions between the prepuce and the glans. It occurs in ∼10% of boys at 3 years of age, but decreases to ∼1% of boys by 16 years of age. Since the patient is asymptomatic, with no signs of urinary obstruction, infection (balanoposthitis), or pathologic scarring, the most appropriate management is reassurance and education. The mother should be advised to practice routine hygiene, washing the external genital area, without attempting forceful retraction, which can cause trauma and lead to pathologic phimosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Circumcision is a definitive surgical treatment for phimosis. However, it is reserved for cases of true pathologic phimosis (scarring of the prepuce), recurrent balanoposthitis, or persistent physiologic phimosis that causes problems such as urinary obstruction. This patient is asymptomatic and has a normal developmental finding, making a surgical referral unnecessary and overly aggressive at this stage.

D) INCORRECT:

While gentle stretching may be part of managing persistent phimosis in older children, it is not recommended for a 3-year-old with physiologic phimosis. Forceful retraction, even if gentle, can cause micro-tears, bleeding, and subsequent scarring. This iatrogenic trauma can convert a benign physiologic condition into a pathologic one, making future retraction more difficult.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids are a valid treatment for phimosis, as they can help thin the preputial skin and facilitate retraction. However, this intervention is typically reserved for older boys in whom physiologic phimosis persists, or as a first-line treatment for pathologic phimosis. Given this patient's young age and the asymptomatic, non-pathologic nature of his condition, medical therapy is not yet indicated.
questions.hint: The inability to retract the foreskin, together with the absence of a scarred, fibrotic ring at the tip of the prepuce, is suggestive of physiologic phimosis.
